title: How Helene Chung became Australia's first woman of colour on TV news | Asia News Week | ABC NEWS
description: Legendary journalist Helene Chung was the first woman posted abroad by the ABC when she worked as a foreign correspondent in China in the 1980s. In the decade prior, she paved the way for many others, becoming one of the first reporters of Asian heritage to be seen on Australian TV.   Asia News Week sat down with the fearsome journalist to discuss her incredible career, as the impact of her work is recognised in this year's Chinese Australian achiever awards.  Produced by Kai Feng and Jason Fang.  Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Energy costs won't be lower under Coalition plan, says Malcom Turnbull | ABC NEWS
description: Former Liberal prime minister Malcolm Turnbull says the Coalition still faces ongoing energy and climate challenges, claiming that the right wing and the Nationals have turned these issues into a culture war. Recent Redbridge polling reveals a challenging situation for Liberal leader Sussan Ley, with the Coalition's support dropping to a record low of 24 per cent. In contrast, One Nation's support has risen to a record high of 18 per cent. title: ASX ends the day flat, but has fallen 5.6% from October peak | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: The broad share market index has dropped 5.6% since its peak on October 21st. Macquarie analysts suggest we are in a correction, which they call 'indigestion' after strong economic growth.  Calix stock surged after partnering with Rio Tinto to test zero-emissions steel technology, while Bitcoin and gold are both down. title: Calls to change ASX trading rules after DroneShield share crash | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: After running a dizzying rally this year, DroneShield saw its stock plunge by more than 30 per cent in a day on November 13.  The sell-off came after the news the chief executive Oleg Vornik, chair Peter James and director Jethro Marks offloaded all of their shares in the counter drone technology company.  The company announced the share sales on November 12 after a previous announcement on November 5, that Oleg Vornik, Peter James and Jethro Marks had received performance share options, triggered by the company achieving milestone of $200 million in cash receipts over a 12-month rolling period. They converted the majority of their performance options to ordinary shares, then sold them between November 6 and November 12. Experts say sales like this can affect investor confidence. International corporate governance and sustainability expert Thomas Clarke says there are no rules against it but he thinks there "should be a window to prevent directors selling out the bulk of their shares or a very large proportion of their shares so soon after an announcement."  Investors also are calling for changes to regulations.   DroneShield told the market, the share sales by the CEO and others were unrelated to the growth trajectory of the company, which it said remains strong, as highlighted in the recent quarterly market update. Directors also retain a stake in the company through vested options, but CEO Oleg Vornik holds less than 200,000 vested share options out of the 15 million he was awarded.  DroneShield shares have surged more than 200 per cent this year.  The share price picked up 12 per cent on Monday. ABC contacted Peter James and Jethro Marks through DroneShield and Oleg Vornik for comment. #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Schools remain closed over concerns about asbestos in coloured sand | ABC NEWS
description: Twenty-five public schools in Canberra will remain closed on Tuesday, while dozens will reopen or partially open, due to coloured play sand being possibly contaminated with asbestos. The ACT government shut 70 public schools on Monday after several coloured sand products were recalled by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC). While there is a national recall for coloured sand products over asbestos contamination concerns, only the ACT has gone so far as to close public schools while it cleans up the products. title: South African man who attended Neo-Nazi rally has visa cancelled | ABC NEWS
description: A man who moved to Australia from South Africa in 2022 had his visa cancelled after attending a Neo-Nazi rally at the New South Wales Parliament. Matthew Gruter was among the approximately 60 participants at the protest organised by the National Socialist Network.  NSW Premier Chris Minns plans to introduce changes to hate speech laws in Parliament this week. title: Ex-Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina sentenced to death for crimes against humanity | The World | ABC News
description: Bangladesh's ousted Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been handed a death sentence for the ordering of a deadly crackdown on a student-led protest in 2024. Hasina was absent from the proceedings when a court found her guilty of crimes against humanity. Professor Sreeradha Datta from the Jindal School of International Affairs tells The World's Girish Sawlani the "harsh" verdict was expected given the amount of evidence that had been gathered in the last year. title: Iran in severe drought because of 'water bankruptcy, says former official | The World | ABC News
description: Residents in Iran's capital Tehran are praying for rain in the midst of a severe drought. With record low rainfall levels many of the country's major reservoirs are less than 5 per cent full. The country's President Masoud Pezeshkian is warning Tehran faces evacuation if the winter rains don't come. But it's not all about the climate. Kaveh Madani is the Director of the United Nations University's Institute for Water, Environment and Health, and was also the deputy head of Iran's environment department. He told The World's Girish Sawlani what's happening in Iran is akin to "water bankruptcy".
